_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Introduction

The Dodge Company (DODGE) warehouse is located in Fort Worth, Texas. Senior management is committed to protecting the health of its employees and the general public and is actively developing comprehensive safety management plans to achieve these objectives.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

DODGE manages the facility in compliance with Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA),

Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and United States Department of Transportation (USDOT) regulations. Senior management at the facility is designated as having primary responsibility for ensuring compliance to these programs.



Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances Handled

DODGE provides embalming chemicals for mortuary services. The warehouse stored formaldehyde containing products prior to shipment to clients.  No manufacturing or re-bottling is done at the facility. The warehouse facility in Fort Worth, TX includes a warehouse and administrative area.  DODGE operates one process that stores formaldehyde containing solutions: warehouse storage 



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

DODGE has put in place several measures that serve to prevent/mitigate the release of liquid formaldehyde

in the warehouse and shipping areas. These include:

- Fire extinguishers are located throughout the warehouse areas and personnel that work in this area have been trained on their proper use.

- Personal protection equipment and spill kits are located throughout the warehouse area and personnel that work in this area have been trained on their proper use.

 - Warehouse workers are trained in the proper handling of materials, including forklift operation.



Five Year Accident History

There have been no reportable releases of formaldehyde at the Dodge Company since it began operations.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

DODGE conducted a process hazards analysis (PHA) for the formaldeh

yde process operations in compliance with the EPA's Risk Management Program regulation (40 CFR 68). The PHA was based on a what-if question checklist developed through brainstorming and supplemented with unique site-specific issues to ensure that hazards of this process were thoroughly reviewed. Hazards and applicable recommendations were developed and documented during the PHA. The recommendations for engineering and administrative (E/A) controls for these scenarios and others identified are documented within the PHA What-If Checklist.
